elements.title: Why do we buy what we buy?
elements.contents:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Personal Finance

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

Why do we buy what we buy?

Vox · 14 min

A sociologist on why people buy too many things.

Why everything feels more expensive right now

Vox · 10 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

Investment Firms Aren’t Buying All the Houses. But They Are Buying the Most Important Ones.

Slate · 6 min

The median price of an American house has increased by 28 percent over the last two years, as pandemic-driven demand and long-term demographic changes send buyers into crazed bidding wars. Might the fact that corporate investors snapped up 15 percent of U.S.

This couple retired at 38 in 1991 with $500,000 in savings. Here's how their investments have lasted over the years

CNBC · 1 min

Billy and Akaisha Kaderli feel like they have seen it all. The couple retired in 1991 at the age of 38 after saving $500,000.

What Home Staging Showed Me About Housing in America

catapult.co · 11 min

Home staging is a privileged kind of precariousness.

I’m 62, unemployed, living off my savings and waiting on Social Security — ‘Can I go fishing for the next 25 years and forget about work?’

MarketWatch · 5 min

Have a question about your own retirement savings? Email us at HelpMeRetire@marketwatch.com Hello MarketWatch,  I am a 62-year-old single male and have no children. I decided three years ago to quit work and enjoy my life instead of working in the office from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.

How to Invest in Stocks

The Motley Fool · 8 min

If you are ready to start investing in the stock market, but aren't sure of the first steps to take when investing in stocks, you’ve come to the right place. It might surprise you to learn that a $10,000 investment in the S&P 500 index 50 years ago would be worth nearly $1.2 million today.

Use the 50-30-20 rule to be smarter and more successful with your money

CNBC · 2 min

This story is part of CNBC Make It's One-Minute Money Hacks series, which provides easy, straightforward tips and tricks to help you understand your finances and take control of your money. Managing your finances and setting a monthly budget can be challenging.

Peter Thiel’s $5 Billion Roth IRA Tax Haven Is the Hottest New Investing Tip

VICE · 6 min

A ProPublica investigation exposed how billionaire Peter Thiel used a Roth IRA to dodge millions in taxes. To many in the finance world, it just revealed Thiel as an inspiration.

Real-estate investor Mike Bryant breaks down the strategy he used to acquire 10 properties 'without putting a nickel into' them — and shares why he recently decided to sell all but 4

Business Insider · 4 min

When Mike Bryant was in his early 50s in 2012, he started to think about ways he could further build his retirement portfolio. That's when he turned to real-estate investing. But it can be a tough market to break into, especially without large amounts of cash for a down payment.

‘I put my life savings in crypto’: how a generation of amateurs got hooked on high-risk trading

The Guardian · 16 min

Noor is whispering so her boyfriend won’t hear her. The 30-something designer from London is down about £14,000 as a result of her decision to get into investing, in addition to another £8,000 profit she made on bitcoin last year, but then lost.

Here's how to get $100,000 in annual tax-free income during retirement

CNBC · 6 min

It's a sure bet that no one — regardless of age — enjoys handing over any of their income to the IRS. In retirement, though, doing so can feel like even more of a sting.

Inside Austin’s Wild Real-Estate Market

Curbed · 8 min

In Austin, Texas — where the average summer day peaks at more than 90 degrees — air conditioning seems … important. It’s widely credited for making Texas habitable, and one reason why the state’s population has grown in every single Census since it was admitted to the union.

Should you consider selling your home and renting in retirement?

The Globe and Mail · 4 min

When it comes to home ownership, we Canadians are a committed bunch. About two-thirds of us own our homes, making us among the world leaders in that category. We even have a burgeoning home-equity loan industry to help the home-rich but cash-poor stay in their houses after retiring.

Billionaire Peter Thiel amasses $5bn tax-free nest egg in retirement account

The Guardian · 3 min

Billionaire Peter Thiel, one of the founders of PayPal, has used a retirement account designed to help ordinary Americans save for their golden years to amass a $5bn tax-free nest egg, according to records obtained by ProPublica.

The secret truth of the student debt crisis

The Week · 8 min

The student debt crisis has gotten wide attention over the last several years. Democratic Sens.

The Bank of Canada is charting a path toward a real estate crash

Toronto Star · 3 min

Whether you are a renter or you’re looking to buy, there’s no denying real estate is too expensive in Canada.

World’s Bubbliest Housing Markets Flash 2008 Style Warnings

Bloomberg · 2 min

Real estate prices around the world are flashing the kind of bubble warnings that haven’t been seen since the run up to the 2008 financial crisis, according to Bloomberg Economics.

Warren Buffett's Investing Strategy: An Inside Look

Investopedia · 3 min

A staunch believer in the value-based investing model, investment guru Warren Buffett has long held the belief that people should only buy stocks in companies that exhibit solid fundamentals, strong earnings power, and the potential for continued growth.

Opinion: Your 401(k) fees could cost you half a million dollars in retirement

MarketWatch · 5 min

Ask anyone with a 401(k) plan at work what they pay in fees and the answers may surprise you: Most people think they pay nothing at all. Even those who know that’s impossible undershoot by a surprisingly large margin, guessing “about 1%” in fees.

2021 vs. 1992: I couldn’t afford my Toronto house if I had to buy in Canada’s current real estate market

The Globe and Mail · 3 min

Buying a home in the Toronto of 1992 was a bit of a stretch for twentysomething couples, but you got it done without much drama. That’s how I recall things when my wife and I bought our first house almost 30 years ago.

Bitcoin crash opens door to a tax loophole for investors

CNBC · 3 min

Crypto investors may be shellshocked by a recent plunge in prices. But that sell-off has a silver lining: It opens the door to a money saving tax strategy. Popular cryptocurrencies like bitcoin and ethereum shed more than half their value in volatile trading over the past month or so.
